title: Conflict & Repair
description: Learn how you handle disagreements and reconnect afterward.

questions.text: During conflict, what do I need most from you?

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict needs vary dramatically and mismatched approaches escalate rather than resolve. Validation-seekers need to feel understood; space-seekers need time to regulate; calm-seekers need low intensity; reassurance-seekers need relational safety. Giving your partner what they need during conflict de-escalates faster than insisting on your own style.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different conflict needs are one of the most common relationship challenges. The validation-seeker feels abandoned by the space-seeker; the calm-seeker feels overwhelmed by intensity. Learn to meet your partner's need before pressing your own.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conflict needs make disagreements more manageable. You'll naturally give each other what helps during tense moments.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you most need from your partner during conflict? Do they know this? What happens when they give you something else instead?

questions.text: What's my typical response when we argue?
choices: I want to talk it through immediately
I need to withdraw and process alone
I try to fix or solve the problem
I get defensive and explain my side

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict responses often reflect attachment patterns. Pursuers want immediate resolution through connection; withdrawers need self-regulation before engaging; fixers focus on problem-solving; defenders protect themselves from criticism. Understanding your and your partner's patterns helps you navigate conflict without triggering each other's defenses.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different conflict responses create the classic pursuer-withdrawer dynamic—one chases while the other retreats, escalating the cycle. Naming your patterns without judgment helps you interrupt them.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conflict responses can either help (two withdrawers respect space) or harm (two pursuers escalate). Self-awareness about your shared pattern is key.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's your instinctive response when conflict arises? Does this help or hurt your resolution? What would you need to respond differently?

questions.text: How do I prefer to repair after we've argued?
choices: Time to let it pass naturally
A genuine apology from both sides

therapeutic.rationale: Repair—the reconnection after rupture—is essential for relationship health. Talk-through repairers need verbal processing; touch-repairers need physical reconnection; time-passers need natural fade; apology-seekers need accountability. Gottman's research shows that successful repair attempts, more than conflict avoidance, predict relationship success.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different repair styles can extend disconnection unnecessarily. The talk-through repairer may feel unresolved while the time-passer waits; the touch-repairer may feel rejected by the talk-first person. Learn to offer repair in your partner's language.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared repair styles mean you'll naturally reconnect through the same process. Conflict resolution will feel complete to you both at the same time.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you know when conflict is truly over? What helps you feel reconnected after a fight? Does your repair style match your partner's?

questions.text: What makes it hardest for me to move on after conflict?

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict residue—what keeps us from fully moving on—varies by person. Unheard-feelers need validation; understanding-seekers need explanation; worry-holders need reassurance; apology-needers need accountability. Knowing what keeps your partner stuck helps you address the right thing during repair.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different sticking points mean you get stuck for different reasons. Your partner may have moved on while you're still waiting for something you need. Name what's keeping you stuck.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sticking points mean you'll both need the same thing to fully resolve. You understand each other's lingering hurt because it's the same.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: After arguments, what keeps you from fully letting go? What would you need to truly move on? Does your partner know what's keeping you stuck?

questions.text: What's the biggest thing I've learned about conflict in our relationship?
choices: How to actually listen to each other
That repair is more important than avoiding fights
What my own triggers and patterns are

therapeutic.rationale: How we've grown in conflict reveals relationship maturity. Survival-learners have built resilience; listener-learners have developed skills; repair-learners understand reconnection; trigger-aware learners have self-knowledge. Acknowledging conflict growth strengthens confidence in the relationship's ability to weather storms.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different growth areas reveal different lessons learned. Sharing what you've each learned creates mutual appreciation for how far you've come.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared growth areas suggest aligned conflict development. You've both evolved through similar realizations.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How has your relationship with conflict changed since you got together? What have you learned? What would you still like to improve?
